text: [Music]
Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Jessica
Tarlov and today I've got Congressman Ro
K Connor with me. He represents
California's 17th district right in the
heart of Silicon Valley. He's known for
being a bold progressive but also
someone who knows how to work across the
aisle when it counts. Whether it's
taking on corruption in DC with his
drain the swamp act or promoting what he
calls economic patriotism, he's pushing
for a Democratic party that's both
idealistic and grounded. and he's not
exactly subtle with his ambitions. He's
got a clear vision for the party's
future and maybe even his own.
Congressman Kana, it's great to have you
here. Welcome to the show. Thank you for
having me. It's so great. I always see
you on Fox and I'm like, "Yeah, I've got
a buddy here." Um, so it's wonderful to
have you here now on the podcast as
well. I'm honored to. Um, I wanted to
start kind of big picture. Uh people
have been giving their hundred you know
first 100 days assessment but what has
stuck out to you most about what the
Trump administration is doing? Well they
are destroying the economy. I mean they
are using uh 19th century ideas blanket
high tariffs by McKinley uh a sense that
of James Pulk like expansionism
uh without understanding the 21st
century world and the consequence has
been the lowest consumer confidence in
years. the bond yields going up. A
really dangerous situation where you've
got both Mark Carney who was the Bank of
Canada as governor, Bank of England
governor uh threatening to be selling
bonds and now you got Japan threatening
to be selling bonds. I mean they're
upsetting our allies really uh and the
bond yields go up as you know that means
that the debt is going to be a huge
burden. So, they've destabilized
consumer confidence, destabilized the
bond market, uh created volatility in
the stock market, in people's
retirements, uh and small businesses and
manufacturers are having a hard time uh
getting parts. So, I my biggest concern
with them is what they've done to the
economy. The second thing is the
disregard for the constitution. Uh I saw
Carl Ro on the other day and he said, "I
don't understand it. Just bring him
back. Have give him a trial. If he's
guilty, then you can deport him." But
the idea that they've let this drag on
for uh weeks uh and that they have
created fear in this country that any
person uh who's here even if they're on
illegal immigration status could get a
knock on the door and be deported is a
violation of rights and really is
upsetting people's patriotism and in
America are patriotism first and
foremost means an allegiance to the
constitution. Yeah. Well, he uh he's not
a lawyer, so he's not really sure about
his uh constitutional duties at this
point, or at least that's what he told
Kristen Welker. Um, but you're dancing
around this idea of economic patriotism,
which you've been talking about. How do
you Well, first of all, can you define
that for our listeners, but then also
put it in context of the Democratic
Party's leadership because it has been a
big concern of mine that for as terrible

administration, and we see it in the

that Democrats have actually not been

to the American public that we would
actually be able to do a better job. I
will answer the question economic. Just
do want to say that JD Vance is a
lawyer. We both went to Yale Law School
and I gave a major speech at Yale Law
School just a week ago that I hope some
folks will check out calling him out for
basically telling uh the country that
there should be no due process for those
who are not citizens which is a
violation of the 14th amendment and for
calling universities the enemy and
calling for defying of the court. He
knows better. But on economic patriotism
it's pretty simple. We need to say we
understand the economic future and we
want to make sure that every community
in this country particularly communities
that were hollowed out and
de-industrialized that every community
every family every child is going to
have economic security and economic
prosperity uh in the 21st century and
the way we're going to do this is to
build things in this country to build an
economy in every part of this country by
marrying the uh technology of uh places
like Silicon Valley the AI the robotics
with the work ethic, the industrial
capability uh in other parts of the
country to build advanced steel plants,
to build biotechnology, to build uh new
industry, but also to have AImmies
across this country that have uh
manufacturing work hubs across the
country at universities and then we can
go into the specifics. I would just
provide three simple ones. have a White
House economic development council like
we have a White House National Security
Council that has a Marshall Plan for
America and the development of every
community uh in this country. Make sure
that we're financing the workforce and
the new factories that we want. Let's
also make sure we're financing
technology uh and education and
healthcare. Recognizing that communities
to have economic development are going
to diversify. Yes, they need advanced
manufacturing factories, but they also
need uh other sectors. And let's build
this in places like Lorraine and
Johntown and Milwaukee across this
country to help bring this country
together. Well, that sounds great. And
it sounds like what Howard Letic wishes
that he was able to say when he does
these haphazard interviews, when I'm
being generous with the term haphazard,
how have you found that the vision that
you just put forward is being embraced
by our party? Well, Lick has got all the
right buzzwords. He would say, "Oh, I
agree with Ro. We need to uh have
manufacturing. We need to have steel. We

universities to build that technology

going to have tariffs but tariffs with
with you can't protect industry until
you build industry. and tariffs are uh
hurting the manufacturers actually
getting the supply parts before we built
the supply chain uh here. Uh so that is
the the fundamental challenge with uh
let one other point he said he had I
wish he had few economists around him.
He said in this speech that uh if we
lower the trade deficit by $300 billion
we're going to increase our GDP by $300
billion. I wish it was that simple. And
so if we eliminate the trillion dollar
uh trade deficit, magically we'd have 3%
GDP growth overnight. The problem with
that reasoning uh is that uh if you
lower if you increase uh domestic
production by lowering the trade
deficit, you also reduce capital inflows
and capital inflows go to lower treasury
bond yields which go to domestic
manufacturing. I know it's a little bit
wonky, but it's not a onetoone
relationship. Now, most people don't
need to know that, but the commerce
secretary does. can't be spouting
economic nonsense uh and expect to
rebuild uh the country. I I think
Democrats need a greater fluency in the
language of the economy. I think we need
a greater sense of understanding that
you have to not just have economic
fairness but economic growth. We need to
be a party that stands for building
things. We need to be a party that is
not afraid to involve business leaders
in uh in in the economic renewal of this
country. We need to be a party that

country. And I I think there there's
going to be a clash of ideas for the
democratic future. I I have my ideas
that I'd like to to to to share and that
I believe resonate in places like
Lorraine, Ohio and Johntown,
Pennsylvania and uh Orangeburg, South
Carolina. But other people have
different visions and that's good. Let's
just make sure it's not a uh a a a top-
down process and a stale process that we
really have a clash of ideas and uh and
think of what can move this country
forward. Yeah. I wanted to ask you about
your future plans later in the podcast,
but you kind of brought it up already.
So, how do you see yourself as being
part of the conversation and shaping the
party's future? Are you thinking about
running yourself
or supporting someone who has kind of an
aligned vision or running yourself?
Well, it could be either. I don't I
don't know. And what I want to be is a
strong economic voice in the country
country. I'd love for others to take my
platform. I mean, I it's up out there. I
write books. I write uh articles. One of

Deluzio liked it and he created a whole

Craig and Chrissy Hulahad all commit
committed to this agenda of economic
renewal, economic revitalization. Uh and
so I I want to be a strong economic
voice for the party. I want our party to
when people think of who's going to lead
America into the economic future. Who's
going to grow America's economy? Who's
going to make sure that this country is
wealthy not from a 19th century
perspective at a 21st century
perspective? who's gonna build economic
security for families and communities in
this time. I want people to think of the
Democratic Party and I want people to
say Roana played a role in getting the
Democratic party to that. Yeah, I
imagine that they're going to and one
thing that I've always felt that you've
done really well is have the strong
progressive bonafidees but also be able
to speak like you just did to the fact
that we are a capitalist country and
that capitalism is one of, if not the
greatest engine for good. It felt
distinctive at this moment where
Democrats are kind of trying to claw at
anything that was anti- Elon Elon Musk
for you to just have this common sense
approach to answering the question about
an American company, but also about
capitalism and saying we have to be able
to separate whatever our political
ambitions are or whatever is resonating
the most, which is this anti- Elon
messaging, with what's actually right
for the country. Absolutely. I mean
look, we should be cheering for the
success of American companies. We should
be cheering uh for American companies to
build wealth but then to pay workers
well to give workers equity in there to
allow for labor neutrality and
unionization to invest across the
country. But I I I am a believer in
technology. I'm a believer in
entrepreneurship. I'm a believer that
you have to have the government
investment to build the infrastructure.
That's what DARPA did. That's what uh uh
NSF did with the internet. Uh but then
you need uh private companies to help
scale it and commercialize it. And why
do you need private companies to do that
as opposed to the government? Because it
requires a lot of uh adjustments and
testing and uh changes uh and it has to
be done very fast to be able to scale.
And it is the collaboration between that
government investment and the private
sector that has uh allowed for America
to emerge as the greatest economy in the
world. And that is what we need not just
uh in places like Silicon Valley but
around the country. Do you think that
trying to bucket people into progressive
or centrist moderates is outdated for
our party? I I no. I mean I think that I
call myself a progressive capitalist. a
pro business progressive, but there
there are definitely uh differences of
opinion. I mean, I'm proud of the
progressive views I have on saying that
uh we need Medicare for all or saying
that we need to have higher taxes on uh
on on billionaires in my district or
saying that we need a a living wage. But
I also believe that can have uh a a a
belief in economic growth and
innovation. I don't think that there are
people who are uh centrists or moderates
who may disagree with Medicare for all
or may not agree that we need uh uh
higher taxes on uh on on on the wealthy
and and that's fine. We shouldn't be
afraid. In the Democratic party, we sort
of have this uh fear of a clash of
ideas. And on the Republican side, they
argue all the time that I I don't I I
think our party has been too stale. Uh
has been too timid. uh has had the same
sort of cast of characters around and
and we need to shake things up. Oh, 2028
will definitely be a big shakeup.

Can you talk a little bit about your
legislation, the Drain the Swamp Act,
which you recently introduced with
representatives Tibb and Lee? So, we're
introducing a couple uh bills. The Drain
the Swamp Act is the most obvious.
President Biden left saying there should
be a ban on White House uh officials
getting gifts from lobbyists. That was
the executive order Biden had and the
rule in his administration. President
Trump comes in and he takes that
executive order away. Now I said, "How
is that drained the swamp?" So now White
House officials can get gifts from
lobbyists. Why don't we have a drain the
swamp act that prohibits White House
officials, not just during Trump, but
from any future White House from getting
gifts from lobbyists? We as Democrats
need to take the mantle uh to against
political corruption. I mean, I was
flabbergasted yesterday. I read that
there is a small business uh that is
paying $20 million to Donald Trump's
memecoin. They're buying $20 million and
the CEO is bragging that he's hoping
that he's going to get exemptions uh for
the trade negotiations with Mexico. How
is this happening in plain sight and we
aren't railing against it? Our party
should be the party that says we don't
take pack money. We don't take lobbyist
money. We should be against super PACs.
Uh abolish them. Uh no one should be
giving allowed to give millions of
dollars to a super PAC when they can
only give $3500 to the candidate. That's
similarly in my bill to to to to to do
that. And Maine passed that by 70%. We
should be of course against stock
trading. We should be the party that
says uh we're not for members of
Congress becoming lobbyists. Uh that
lobbyists shouldn't be able to give
members money or gifts or White House
officials gifts. that no elected
official should be able to trade in
means. Let's become the party that says,
"Let's clean up the mess." I feel like
we are always that party, right, who
says these things and then you come up
against the fact that the laws haven't
changed and you're going to be
handicapped versus another side that can
take infinite money from super PACs or
that can be building resorts in the
Middle East or whatever it is that
Kushner and and Don Jr. are doing at
this point. And does it kind of feel
like we would be showing up to a
gunfight with a knife if we but you know
I I think we can advocate to the
legislation first of all to uh to to
stop it before uh you know voluntarily
complying. Where I do think we should
voluntarily comply is in Democratic
primaries. I mean, if look, if the
Republican nominee is Donald Trump, uh,
in the past, I had no problem that Mark
Kla Harris had to, uh, match the the
spending, but we don't need to do that
in a in a Democratic primary. We can say
there can't be unilateral disarmament
against a Republican, but that shouldn't
apply to a Democratic primary. I guess
the newsiest bizarre things uh that

centric the movie tariffs and reopening
of Alcatraz which has you know was a

$60 million a year at this point. Uh
what do you make of the proposals? Do

to hurt Hollywood. I mean, Trump knows
that uh we export far more movies than
we import, and that the only thing this
is going to do is vert Hollywood, which
he uh has been waging a cultural war on.
So, I I I stand very strongly with uh
with the the the American uh film
industry to say that we don't want to

like him talking about taking over

wants to change away from some degree
are this proposed $880 billion in cuts
to Medicaid. Can you talk about what's

a devastating these Medicaid cuts and I

It's it's makes no sense. uh and uh two

doing a we're being very aggressive in

and I'm confident that he's going to be

Two two places of fear. Uh immigrants
who show up say, "I'm concerned for my

It's a scary place in America if you are

not because they're looking for a

And uh they're fearful that this is
going to be snatched away from them. How

can't be heard. That's the biggest

Republicans have said they don't do a

thousand people show up and they just

in some cases these town halls have
worked. Republicans have flipped their

to cut Medicaid. Voted to cut Medicaid.
We did our town hall a few weeks later.
He said now he's against the cut. So
people are seeing that they're speaking
up is working and that's what gives me
hope in this country. I mean we are

to town hall showing up to protest. Uh
there's a Harvard professor who said
that society is moving towards

uh safeguard against a move towards

And you did see like there was an

nonviolent of course
is the way forward? I do and I was so uh

can't you can't be deporting kids in
this country. They were that's not who
we are as Americans. And I I I have seen

haven't witnessed my whole life. People
are reclaiming their rights as citizens.
They find it offensive that the world's

offensive that any person, even if
they're president, can get to defy the

the uh the the the services that they've

uh and they are speaking out and
immobilized citizenry uh is un

everything and so I appreciate the
people who are spending hours standing

standing in line going to rallies uh
writing to their members of Congress. It
all matter. Don't let people tell you it

in certain cases uh people the media is

some of them are being stopped. Uh it's
it's not Congress. It's it's not the

The other check has been the American
citizens. So you're optimistic.
I'm very optimistic. I you know the uh
it's always darkest before the dawn. And
uh in American history after the civil

looking at our approval ratings, I'm
certainly concerned, but the way that
you paint it makes me think there there
will be a brighter day to come. What's

the attacks on universities in this

It's that they are the place for uh

hypocrisy uh and is really

the the factories had shut down, the

And so I believe that uh people will uh
